prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author of the "Am I the Asshole?" post is in the wrong for not attending their best friend's wedding. The situation is that the friend didn't send save-the-dates and only sent invitations a month before the wedding. The author and their friends had already planned a trip to Australia that starts two days before the wedding, and they can't cancel because it's a big financial loss. The friend is upset and expects them to drop everything.

First, I need to consider the norms around weddings. Typically, save-the-dates are sent out several months in advance, maybe 6-8 months, and formal invitations a couple of months before. Here, the friend sent invitations just a month before, which is short notice. That's on the friend. Also, the author had already planned a trip and informed the friend about it. The friend might have forgotten or not considered the timing. 

The author's argument is that they can't afford to cancel the trip. Financial commitment is a real issue, especially for people not in a wealthy position. The friend invited 50 people but only 20 can make it because of the short notice. That shows the friend might have known that many people might not be able to come, yet still expected the author to be there. 

The key points here: the friend didn't give proper notice, the trip was planned before the wedding, and the author can't afford to cancel. The friend's reaction seems unreasonable given the circumstances. While it's understandable that the friend is upset, the fault isn't entirely on the author. The author isn't at fault here because the planning and financial aspects are valid reasons. So the answer should be B, the author is not in the wrong.
